13. Pictures from an Exhibition / Картинки с выставки

by Sasha Sokolov

Translated by Alexander Boguslawski

The hoarfrost—may pass. The chickens—may walk over the sand, looking surprised that they leave prints with their chicken feet. Not to like these birds, but to like watching how they leave prints on the wet sand, without suspecting it, without suspecting anything. The chatterboxes could be heard. They kept shouting to each other but did not halloo because they were walking together, in a tight flock. Moira, who was spending her overripe years on the bench in the front yard, also heard the voices. Then she put aside her knitting needles, with which she had been picking in her ears since morning, jumped up, looked carefully in that direction, and cawed: They are leading her. A ball of gray wool rolled off her knees, hopped on the flower bed, and, crushing the anemic anemones, rolled somewhere, having turned into a ball of courting vipers. The barracks—may wait. Stepping into the space of April delight, they kept saying: They are leading her; she has had enough swinging. The complex, mixed smell of roll-ups and state-rolled papirosy may soar above the gathering of the interested. Not to know anybody here. The delinquent tenant, living in the truncated room under the stairs, was outside; he may hang out at the water reservoir, near the boathouses, begging shameless oarswomen for candy wrappers. Brawny trainers, people of middle age, humiliated the scrounger. She was walking with her hair loose, having thrown her head back to see only the azure. Her white demi-saison coat is unbuttoned. But tomorrow it will get warmer—and she is already in a sarafan. And the witches—in black. The highway is violet, covered with purple puddles, and if we continue with the colors, with impressions—then the tiny young leaves, on the background of which the walk is taking place, convey to us the impression of green smoke. Two ghastly skin-and-bones are holding her under her arms. The others are walking in a circle, guarding, and all are trying to touch. For a long time, for several moments, he has been observing what was happening there; he has been observing it from his window for several years. At first—just once; later—occasionally and then—constantly. Whenever, wherever: the black jubilant centipede, the hunchbacked semibasement wood louse. The time of year and day is changing, the long dresses of the flock are turning into longskirted sacks. The decorations and lighting and the footwear of the extras are changing, but their gestures, grimaces, and gait do not show any variations. When it is October and the melted butter of the slush spreads on the stale zwieback of the blacktop; whether there is fog, and mildew, God’s false milky dew, oozes down the gutters of the old women’s wrinkles; if it is late, dark, and the pieces of glass from broken bottles glimmer neither in the harbor nor in the trash of garbage piles; or when January puts wind-and-snow gags in the thin-lipped mouths of the babblers; or February-crooked-paths, having outfitted itself with the pincers of snowstorms, tries to tear out the sinewy tongues of the prophetic tattlers; or when it is summer, but it is cloudy, and the stratocumuli, udder-shaped, grow, ripen above the site—when and whether, and if, and wherever, and while—then, therefore, and consequently, it follows that no one will notice the approach of the expedition, and even if one notices, one will not caw, and if one does caw, one will not be heard, and if one is heard, there will be no response: Cozying up in the warm daze of kerosene, fearing polyps and glands, the barracks will not meet her, will not look out. Only you, the apprentice-enchanter, pretending to be the admirer of the Celsius scale but actually evaluating the universe—more precisely, one of its paths—every time you will discover them again on their way to the plywood dwelling. If the light dimmed, went out, the ne’er-do-wells would light the candle ends. You will see them—poor, shaggy, and ugly; their features are revolting. However, when the procession came down from the railroad embankment, came closer to the gardens populated by stooping scarecrows, when it stepped on the solid ground of the yard flattened by children’s games and printing chicken feet, then everything achieved by the blabbermouths in the case of overcoming distances turned into purest fiction. Not thinking about going back, not making even a step backward, the procession has already returned, transferred, moved to the starting position, toward the horizon, and clearly not noticing what happened, continues what had been started—walks, marches, goes forward, dragging and pushing, urging and scolding the one whose head is thrown back and crowned with a quite tainted—but from afar, through the cleansing crystal of empty space, astonishingly fresh ribbon. And when, many Aprils later, one of the disobedient pupils of the courier institute will become an accidental witness of the Sisyphean gliding next to the river-cesspool, it, despite all its particulars, will not seem to the inspired youngster like a frightening revelation. He will juxtapose, compare both marches, and note their similar and different features. Both of them—you will assure yourself, having turned with the help of the flannel into something resembling a cocoon and going to the official dormitory sleep—both of them are symptoms of terminal temporal disease that distorted the natural flow of events and years, the flow of being, the course of the flow. And winter did visit—all in cheviot coats and thaws. It came, feverishly breathing with the bowels of the bed table; it was a sum of smells—asidol, paste, wax, a dirt-cheap remedy, called without beating around the bushes a remedy against sores, soap, and, of course, Maria biscuits, sent by their namesake in a registered package. You would have preferred if winter wafted with Matthiola, you would have desired the aroma of Hawaiian amalia, but you did not wince, did not turn away in disgust, fearing that it would get offended and pass, while you wanted to remember it as well as possible—so the next day, in spring, having left the cocoon before the bugle of reveille, you would offer the meeting to pencil and gouache. It came and kept breathing. With an ashen mane, strange, and clinking with horseshoes made of ice. And to wake up in flowers and cicadas, under the camel-embroidered sheet that suddenly became too small. And to wake up in an Egyptian sarcophagus, in a hunting hideout made of tree branches, in the tower of Monsieur Flaubert, in the one in Pisa, in a hollow of a thousand-year-old baobab, having changed into a large longeared koala, hanging with its ears down. And to wake up meaning nothing, as a handful of ash from Tushino, firmly jammed into a Tula mortar. Maria is leaving; it is dawn. To crack, to fry, and to eat three eggs. To feed the crumbs to two tweeting fugel. They will finish pecking, clean their feathers, and tweet again. And other birds, beyond the window, were flying in the direction of the sun, and some were sitting on whitish branches, and others still were trying to print on the roseate frozen sand, but unfortunately they were leaving no tracks. Looking askance at the factory, at the smokes from distant plants, and at the laborer who, straining himself, pushed along the planks the overtime wagtail with junk, the celestial body was coming up. A <em>Visit of the Ragpicker. The genre-painter-wanderer is not needed and not known. The cook of an impoverished aristocrat is treating with some leftovers the suitor who dropped in for an hour. They are having tea in the kitchen at the sticky table. The door to the backyard is partially open; a cart loaded with noble junk can be seen there. Right beyond the backyard begins the backdrop. Behind it, a drinking joint, a schlagbaum, verstas of blurry road, a jail, Siberia, and a cemetery are lined up. The visitor is poorly groomed, unbuttoned, with a face like a trough; his visage bears traces of all kinds of excesses, while the cook is by and large untidy, and her master, the emaciated graying dotard, hiding for some reason in the larder and gingerly looking through his lorgnon at the laborer (the most faded corner of the painting), having slightly pushed aside the filthy curtain with his refined, long-fingered hand, her master—in a nightcap and some kind of cheap undergarment with frayed lace of jabot and cuffs—is a total slob. And should we not wake up at his ancestral estate? In the library? On the ornate settee? On the best days of its owner? As him in person? The works of the departed overachievers may start glimmering in the bookcases with the gold stamping of their spines, as soon as Selene, the brainless child of deaf and mute dusk, seemingly having swallowed itself and astonished and proud of it, Selene with the features of a dictatorial idiot, gulps with her sardonic mouth, with the pores of her highborn face the darkness of the study, and the light may dominate, and everything that is able to reflect, mirror, shine, and glimmer—all this may glimmer, shine, mirror, and reflect. But then the stirring of poplars, the rustling of their meaty leaves may forecast the sudden morning, and the moon may already start fading and falling back, tumbling backward, like during an attack of epilepsy, rolling off the roofs as a not-yet-eaten round bun, dropping behind them, dripping into the corrugated auricle, where big-cheeked pipers pipe on Saturdays, plunging into the park of cultural recreation, into clusters of planted plane trees and the stirring lindens—rolling off, plunging, and spinning among them like a Ferris wheel. The morning dawn dethroned, diminished the moon; this way its fame was ending. The heavenly light penetrated your closed eyelids, and your face was soaring. But even in those moments of your youth, filled with lofty visions, you, then a common apprentice courier, would not ever dare to assume that a time will come—and you will become a whipper-in. The early brooms and the scratching of bread trays being taken out of the crates of the bread carriage, and the squeal of the same trays, sliding diagonally into the underworld: the bread of someone’s early years. And someone of advanced years was walking by. He was walking slowly. He was walking, afflicted by shortness of breath and by foul language. He was walking for a long time. But even he passed by. And a while later the first electric clunker escaped from the purple fingers of Aurora—it was gliding over the rails, hissing with bearings and trolleys, and: But, look, the morn, in russet mantle clad, walks o’er the dew of yon high eastward hill—was posted on the route-board in hieroglyphics corresponding to the occasion. But the transport-absence of people did not last long: The coffeepot has not had time to boil yet, when along the entire street the self-propelled and chock-full-filled equipages already started making noise. The passengers’ appearance seemed disagreeable, like the smell of the open, but as ill luck would have it, jammed umbrellas, which from the frowning point of view so vividly resemble armpits of archaeopteryxes and which the provincials keep sticking in each other’s noses, having burst in, enthusiastically wet, at the stop named Theater, and having burst out, enthusiastically dry, after the premiere that opened another Aesopian season. Inconspicuous cricket of the outskirts, in October you are particularly mysterious. Sad-eyed, you listlessly soar as a patchy mist, walking quietly in the evening from the swings, from the slipways, from the waves of motorboats, gray like the wet sailcloth. You appear, walk out, step on the young thistle before the highway, then—on the highway, then—on the young thistle beyond it, on the cozy gully of Neglect, on beloved, hated—cross out what is not needed—fences and roofs, in order to dreamily, and blindly, and coolly mask it all, shield it, cover it, hide it from strangers’ beholding, swirling, wriggling, and writhing noiselessly, and as if you were squashed between five and six o’clock. You are shielding it, covering it, hiding it, and if one asks from what, you will not answer; perhaps you do not know the answer? No, you do know, but you will not answer—and that is all. You will only answer someday, after going through your youth, after grieving, after burning up, but, as before, being envious of strangers in that old place, you will answer to everything. Foolish girl, an orphan and a child of orphans of this land, I am calling you—look back. Do you know how bright and clean is your unwashed face and how many earthly sorrows of your sisters are combined in its unearthly features? Lonely and lone among all the lone and lonely who are countless, burn, burn brightly—there, at the cobblestone highway; here, at the crossroads of turnouts, and at the dead end, where the burdock grows. Burn with white light, sinless flower, burn, bitter, burn, timid, burn, enchanting. Burn for Yakov, burn for everyone who is rushing to your light in confusion. From Saint George to the Intercession, from the river’s standing to the river’s flowing and from the black fields to the white roads sheltering autumn—burn through the summer, burn through the winter, and as a white shepherd’s star spread everywhere gentle light, your secret charity. Be merry—your image is perennial, not involved in anything, and out of this world. There, on the cobblestone highway, here, on the crossroads of turnouts, burn incessantly in the circle of the funereal old women’s heads that resemble firebrands—gray and smoldering. On that cemetery or on that hill—show white from a distance, burn rising up, captured by the army of crosses similar to warriors mounting brownish mounds. Come merry—to proclaim on the entire firmament your frenetic balabala. And the dusks cometh and the dark flyers gather toward the night into black flocks—and only the boundless spaces up high pay heed to this answer.

Изморози — перейти. Курам — ходить по песку, удивленно печатая своими курьими ножками. Не любить этих птиц, но любить наблюдать, как печатают на мокром песке, не подозревая об этом; и ни о чем. Балаболки заслышались. Перекликались, но не аукались, ибо шли вместе, сплоченной стаей. Мойра, проводившая в палисаднике на скамейке свои перезрелые годы, тоже зачуяла голоса. Тогда она отложила спицы, которыми с утра ковыряла в ушах, привскочила, всмотрелась в ту сторону и выкаркнула: ведут. Клубок серой шерсти скатился с ее колен, скакнул на клумбу и, сминая анемические ханимуны, покатился куда-то клубком брачующихся гадюк. Баракам — ждать. Выступая в пространство апрельской прелести, говорили: ведут, накачалась. Сложному, смешанному духу самокруток и папирос государственного кручения витать над собранием интересующихся. Никого тут не знать. Неплательщик, бытующий в усеченной каморке под лестницей, был вне, ему — пропадать на хранилище вод, у эллингов, клянча фантики у бесстыжих гребчих. Мускулистые тренеры, люди среднего возраста, уничижали просителя. Шла с распущенными, голову запрокинув, чтоб видеть сплошное синее. Белое демисезонное, распахнутое. Но завтра пригреет — и уже в сарафане. А кикиморы — в черном. Шоссе фиолетовое, в лиловых лужах, и если еще о красках, о впечатлении, то вот — мелкая молодая листва, на фоне которой дается шествие, сообщает вам впечатленье зеленого дыма. Две смертельно костлявые — по́д руки. Прочие шли, охраняя, кольцом и все искали дотронуться. Уже давно, несколько мгновений, замечал происходившее там, несколько лет замечал все из окна. Впервые — когда-то, потом — то и знай, а затем — постоянно. Когда бы, куда бы ни: черная ликующая сороконожка, горбатая мокрица полуподвальная. Меняется время года и дня, длинные платья стаи меняются на долгополые балахоны. Меняются декорации, освещение, обувь статисток, но жесты, гримасы, походка — не обнаруживают варьяций. Когда октябрь и на черствый сухарь гудрона ложится топленое масло слякоти; поскольку туман и по сточным канавам старушьих морщин сочится милдью, ложно-мучнистая божья роса; если поздно, темно и осколки бутылочного стекла не блестят ни у пристани, ни в мусоре мусорных куч; то ли январь ставит болтухам ветроснежные кляпы в их тощегубые рты; ниже февраль-кривотроп, снабдившись клещами вьюг, тщится вытащить вещим трещоткам их сухожилые языки; или же лето, но пасмурно, и растут, возрастают над местностью слоисто-кучевые, вымеобразные, — когда и поскольку, да если, да то ли, да или — тогда и постольку, и следовательно, стало быть, — никто не заметит приближения экспедиции, а и заметит — не выкаркнет, а выкаркнет — не будет услышан, а будет — безрезультатно: ютясь в керосиновом теплом чаду, опасаясь полипов и гланд, бараки не встретят, не выглянут. Лишь ты, начинающий лицедей, прикинувшись ревнителем цельсиевой шкалы, а в действительности оценивая мирозданье, точнее, один из его путей, всякий раз обнаружишь их снова на пути их к фанерной обители. Если свет помрачился, угас, злыдни засветят свечные огарки. Бедных, косматых и некрасивых узришь ты; черты их истошны. Стоило шествию, впрочем, спуститься с насыпи, приблизиться к огородам, где сутулились пугала, ступить на убитую детскими играми и печатными курьими ножками дворовую твердь, как все достигнутое балаболками в деле преодоления расстояний оборачивалось фикцией чистейшей воды. Не помышляя вернуться, не отступив назад ни на шаг, шествие уже возвращено, сдвинуто, смещено на исходные рубежи, к горизонту, и, явно не замечая случившегося, продолжает однажды начатое — шествует, марширует, шагает, влача и толкая, понукая и поучая ту, чья голова запрокинута и увенчана столь несвежим, а издали — чрез очищающий кристалл пустоты — бантом поразительной свежести. И когда немало апрелей спустя один из ослушников разъездного училища окажется невольным свидетелем сизифова скольжения при клоакереке, оно, со всеми его особенностями, не явится вдохновенному юноше пугающим откровением. Сопоставит, сравнит два марша, отметит их сходственные черты и различия. Превратившись при помощи байки в подобье кокона: они оба, заверишь как-то себя, грядущего на казенный общежитейский сон, они оба — симптомы неизлечимого временно́го недуга, исказившего естественное теченье событий и лет, течение бытия, русло течения. И зима навестила — вся в шевиотах и оттепелях. Пришла, горячо дыша нутром прикроватной тумбочки; то была сумма запахов — асидол, паста, вакса, копеечное средство, названное безо всяких обиняков средством против потертостей, мыло и, разумеется, галеты Мария, присланные ею заказной бандеролью. Ты предпочел бы зиму, веющую маттиолой, желал бы аромата гавайской амалии, однако не морщился, не отворачивался неприязненно из опасения, что обидится и пройдет, а ты ведь хотел получше запомнить ее — дабы на завтра, весной, оставив кокон до рога побудки, предать свидание карандашу и гуаши. Пришла и дышала. Пеплогривая, странная, цокающая ледяными подковами. И очнуться в цветах и цикадах, под одеялом с вышитыми верблюдами, которое вдруг стало мало. И очнуться в египетском саркофаге, в охотничьем шалаше, в башне господина Флобера, в Пизанской, в дупле тысячелетнего баобаба, обернувшись большим большеухим коала, вниз ушами висящим. И очнуться в значении, равном нулю, в качестве тушинской пригоршни праха, туго забитой в тульский мортир. Мария уходит, рассвет. Разбить и поджарить и съесть три яйца. Крошками хлеба кормить свиристящих двух птах. Склюют и почистят перья и снова засвиристят. А другие птицы за стеклами летели в сторону солнца, а другие сидели на белесых ветвях, а четвертые пытались печатать на смерзшемся розоватом песке, но следов, к сожалению, не оставалось. Искоса глядя на фабрику, на дымы отдаленных заводов и на работника, что, страдая, катил по настилам сверхурочную трясогузку с тряпьем, восходило светило. Визит тряпкореза. Жанрист-передвижник не нужен и неизвестен. Кухарка разорившегося аристократа потчует чем-нибудь завалящим заглянувшего на часок ухажера. Чаевничают на кухне за липким столом. Двери на задний двор приоткрыты, видна тележка, груженная благородным старьем. Непосредственно за двором берут начало задворки. За ними угадываются: кабак, шлагбаум, версты размытого тракта, острог, Сибирь и погост. Визитер неухожен, расхристан, корытолиц, его обличье носит следы всевозможных излишеств; кухарка ж вообще нехалява, а барин ее, худосочный седеющий рамоли, отчего-то прячущийся в чулане и робко лорнирующий работника (самый жухлый угол живописи), слегка отведя изысканной длиннопалой рукою замызганную занавеску, сам хозяин, в ночном колпаке и каком-то убогом, с обремканными кружевами жабо и манжет исподнем, — совершеннейший нехолюза. Да не очнуться ль в его родовом поместье? в библиотеке? на витиеватой козетке? в лучшие дни владельца? им же самим? Сочинениям честолюбцев покойных мерцать в шкапах золотыми тиснениями корешков, коль скоро Селене, безмозглому детищу глухонемого сумрака, будто бы проглотившей себя и тем потрясенной и возгордившейся, Селене с чертами диктаторствующей идиотки — вбирать своим сардоническим ртом, по́рами своего высокосиятельствующего лица кабинетную темноту, и свету — преобладать, и всему, что способно отсвечивать, отражать, блестеть и поблескивать — всему тому поблескивать, блестеть, отражать и отсвечивать. Но вот шевелению тополей, шебуршению их мясистой листвы — предвестить скоропостижное утро, и луне начинать уже меркнуть и запрокидываться, закидываться, как в припадке падучей, скатываться с крыш несъеденным колобком, закатываться за них, капать в гофрированную ушную раковину, куда дудят по субботам щекастые дудари, сваливаться в парк культурного отдыха, в купы платных платанов и лип с их шевеленьем — скатываться, сваливаться и вертеться меж ними чертовым колесом. Заря развенчивала, умаляла луну; так проходила ее слава. Сияние с неба проницало смеженные веки твои, и лицо твое реяло. Но даже и в эти, исполненные высоких прозрений мгновения младости ты, в то время обыкновенный стажирующийся разъездной, не осмелился бы и предположить, что настанет пора — и ты сделаешься доезжачим. Первые метлы и скрежет хлебных лотков, изымаемых из ячей хлебовозов, и визг тех же лотков, съезжающих в преисподнюю по наклонной: хлеб чьих-то ранних лет. А некто лет поздних шел мимо. Шел медленно. Шел, страдая одышкой и сквернословьем. Шел долго. Но миновал и он. А несколько погодя из пу́рпурных перст Авроры выскользнула первая электрическая колымага — скользила по рельсам, шипела подшипниками и троллеями, и: Вот и утро в мантии багряной ступает по росе восточных гор, — опубликовано было на маршрутной табличке приличествующими случаю иероглифами. Но транспортное безлюдье длилось недолго: кофейник еще не успел закипеть, а уже вдоль всей улицы самокатно шумели битком набитые экипажи. Вид пассажиров казался уныл, словно запах раскрытых, заклинивших, как назло, зонтов, которые с точки зрения исподлобья так живо напоминают подмышки археоптериксов и которыми так и тычут друг другу в нос восторженно-сыро ворвавшиеся на остановке Театр провинциалы после премьеры, открывшей очередной эзопов сезон. Неприметный сверчок окраин, в октябре ты особенно скрытен. Грустноглазый, вяло реешь клочковатою мгой, вечером тихо идя от качелей, от стапелей, от серых, как мокрая парусина, водно-моторных волн. Возникаешь, исходишь, находишь на: мелкий татарник перед шоссе, потом — на шоссе, на мелкий татарник за ним, на уютную балку Пренебрежения, на ненаглядные — ненавистные — ненужное зачеркнуть — палисады и кровли, чтоб и сонно, и слепо, и холодно заслонить это все, спрятать, сокрыть, утаить от чуждых свидетельств — клубясь, извиваясь и корчась раздавленно и бесшумно между пятью и шестью. Прячешь, скрываешь, таишь, а если спросить отчего — не ответишь; наверно, не знаешь ответа? нет, знаешь, но не ответишь — и только. Только ответишь когда-нибудь, отъюношествовав, отгоревав, отгорев, но, как и прежде, ревнуя ту давнюю местность к чужим на ней, ответишь за все. Неразумная девочка, сирота и дитя сирот этой земли, я зову тебя — оглянись. Ведаешь ли, как ясен и чист неумытый лик твой и сколько земных печалей сестер твоих слилось в неземных чертах его. Одинокая и единственная из всех единственных и одиноких, коим числа несть, гори-гори ясно — там, на булыжном шоссе, здесь — на разъезжей росстани, и в тупике, где лопух. Гори белым цветом, безгрешным цветком, гори, горькая, гори, робкая, гори, заветная. Гори для Якова, гори для всякого, смятенно спешащего на свет твой. От Георгия до Покрова, от рекостава до рекоплава и от черного поля до белых, осеняющих осень путей — гори вселетье, гори всезимье и белой пастушьей звездой твори повсюду свет кроткий, тайную милость твою. Радуйся — ни к чему не причастен извечный, нездешний твой образ. Там, на булыжном шоссе, здесь — на разъезжей росстани — гори негасимо в кругу погребальных старушьих голов-головешек — седых и чадящих. На том ли погосте, на той ли горе — белей отдаленно, гори вознесенно, плененная воинством людоподобных крестов, бурые бугры оседлавших. Гряди, радуясь,— все-то небо оглашаешь ты кликушеским балабала́. И приидоша сумраки, и темные летуны к ночи совокупляются в черные стаи — и только выспренние пространства внемлют сему ответу.

Chapter Notes

13

Despite its many oddities, Between Dog and Wolf features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC (“How Sokolov’s” 205).

structure
Pictures from an Exhibition

Such an ekphrastic title is borrowed from Modest Mussorgsky’s famous suite of ten piano pieces, composed in 1874. If Mussorgsky’s work intertwines music and pictorial art, in these chapters we see how visual art enters the written dimension of literature. Listen to a recording here.

music intertextuality theme
13

Despite its many oddities, Between Dog and Wolf features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC (“How Sokolov’s” 205).

structure
Картинки с выставки

Such an ekphrastic title is borrowed from Modest Mussorgsky’s famous suite of ten piano pieces, composed in 1874. If Mussorgsky’s work intertwines music and pictorial art, in these chapters we see how visual art enters the written dimension of literature. Listen to a recording here.

music intertextuality theme

Text Annotations

hoarfrost

Rime ice. Frozen water droplets.

explanatory
pass

In the original Russian, the use of infinitives is typical of Yakov’s chapters. They grant the chapters in which he features a timeless quality. On a related note, Richard Borden claims that “Between Dog and Wolf takes place in a circumambient projection of its author’s linguistic consciousness and imagination and that claims for the existence of any more conventional setting would be misleading” (“Toward” 321).

time
The chickens—may walk over the sand, looking surprised that they leave prints with their chicken feet. Not to like these birds, but to like watching how they leave prints on the wet sand, without suspecting it, without suspecting anything

As José Vergara writes, these chickens “resemble the novel’s heroes themselves, who write and write without ever really stopping to consider their ‘prints’ on the sand, surprised at times by what comes of their reflections on the page” (“Flap” 362).

motif language
chickens

Chickens. Animal motif.

motif
chicken

Chickens. Animal motif.

motif
feet

Instead of “lapki” (the usual word defining chicken feet), the author antropomorphizes chickens. Animal motif. Moreover, chicken’s feet are related to the traditional fairy tale of Baba-Yaga and her chicken-legged hut.

language motif folklore

The chickens making noise, clucking. Animal motif.

explanatory motif
flock

Animal motif.

motif
Moira, who was spending her overripe years on the bench in the front yard, also heard the voices. Then she put aside her knitting needles

An allusion to the Fates of Greek myth: Clotho (“spinner”), Lachesis (“allotter”) and Atropos (“the unturnable”). They were said to spin humankind’s fate on looms.

foreign intertextuality
needles

Various characters sew in the novel. In Yakov’s eighth poem, an oriole “resews evening into night” (R172/E39). Sewing is also mentioned in Note XVI (R200/E92). Yakov sews slippers (R274/E219). Sewing theme.

theme intratextuality
anemic anemones

Honeymoon. Flowers in the flowerbed mentioned just before. Ostanin suggests that here it refers to tulips, lilies, or Chinese roses (92). However, it is likely a misspelling or play on “anemone” (commonly called wildflowers). Since they are “anemic,” they are white. According to Sokolov, these flowers are “a variety of fringed tulips, matured ones are half a meter high, but the young sprouts are, of course, small. Anemic means pale, weak, feeble” (personal communication, July 29, 2023). Plant motif.

motif neologism
vipers

Vipers. The period described could then be late Spring, given that the mating season for these snakes is April-May. The timing matches that described in the Notes (ch. 11). Vipers may also be mentioned here because there’s a genus of venomous pit vipers named Lachesis after one of the Moirai just mentioned, Lachesis, who determined the length of the thread of life. Animal motif.

time motif
The barracks—may wait

Personification of the barracks.

poetic device
April

Time setting. The timing matches that described in the Notes (ch. 11).

time
roll-ups

Self-rolled cigarettes.

explanatory
state-rolled

Unusual combination of words: it implies that cigarettes come from a state factory.

explanatory
papirosy

A cigarette with a paper mouthpiece, typically without a filter.

explanatory
living in the truncated room under the stairs

An echo of Ilya’s narrative, which describes a man living under the stairs in Orina and her grandmother’s home.

intratextuality location setting
hang out at the water reservoir

A potential allusion to the poet and translator Spiridon Drozhzhin’s memory and, more specifically, to his house, lost (propadat’) in a water reservoir. The peasant poet Drozhzhin was Rilke’s first translator (and also a close friend). He lived on an island later submerged by the Volga just in front of the gamekeeper’s house where Sokolov lived during his period in Bezborodovo (May 1972–November 1973). According to Mario Caramitti, the character of Krylobyl is but an “hypostasis” of Drozhzhin (“Strategie,” 131).

intertextuality
water reservoir

The water reservoir is first mentioned in chapter 2 (R159/E18). There, Ostanin identifies this dam and reservoir as the Ivankovo Reservoir, also known as the Moscow Sea (24). Located on the northern Volga, in the Moscow and Tver Oblasts, approximately 81 miles (130 km) north of Moscow.

intratextuality location Russia
boathouses

Premises for building or repairing ships ashore. Boat motif.

motif
candy wrappers

According to Ostanin, a reference to a children’s game that uses candy wrappers (92). Watch a tutorial here. Candy wrappers appear three times in the novel (R160, 248, 262/E 19, 174, 199).

explanatory intratextuality
her hair loose

This detail may suggest her being of loose morals.

explanatory
to see only the azure

To see the sky.

explanatory
azure

This color is used several times in the novel in relation to the sky and atmosphere around the Itil (cf. R154, 157, 159, 196–197, 199, 222, 249, 277).

intratextuality
demi-saison coat

“Between seasons” coat. From the French demisaison. Another reference to the time setting (late spring). Clothing motif.

motif time foreign

Sarafan: a long dress worn in Russia. A key aspect of traditional folk culture. Clothing motif.

motif Russia

A folkloric house spirit whose behavior matches that of the homeowner. Asks for food behind the stove or in the basement.

The highway is violet, covered with purple puddles, and if we continue with the colors, with impressions—then the tiny young leaves, on the background of which the walk is taking place, convey to us the impression of green smoke

Synesthesia.

poetic device
skin-and-bones

In folkloric tales, the “kostliavaia” (literally, extremely thin, bony) is the incarnation of death, an allegorical figure, usually depicted as a skeleton wearing a long black cloak (or white shroud) with a scythe. Death theme.

theme folklore
For a long time, for several moments, he has been observing what was happening there; he has been observing it from his window for several years

Yakov spends time watching what is taking place outside his window.

explanatory
milky dew

Plasmopara viticola, the causal agent of grapevine downy mildew. Plant motif. In this chapter different illnesses are mentioned, and Sokolov comments: “it is an unhealthy chapter, which is understandable, because it depicts an unhealthy time in general and in particular: the depressive adolescence of the lyrical hero” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

explanatory motif structure
oozes down the gutters of the old women’s wrinkles

Sokolov explains: “The narrator compares the deep wrinkles of the old women to the ditches through which the dew flows, which has an unpleasant appearance, it resembles mildew, and thus these faces are indirectly compared to diseased leaves” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

explanatory
dark, and the pieces of glass from broken bottles glimmer neither in the harbor nor in the trash of garbage piles

An allusion to Anton Chekhov’s 1886 “The Wolf,” a short story about a man’s encounter with a wolf (Ostanin 93). Read the original here.

intertextuality
January puts wind-and-snow gags in the thin-lipped mouths of the babblers

The snow and wind prevents people from speaking.

explanatory
February-crooked-paths

Sokolov explains: “February is called the month of crooked roads. That’s what they call it: February - crooked roads, that’s the saying. Because this month is the snowiest, and snowstorms sweep away the well-traveled tracks, and village people drive and walk on snowy spaces not straight, but in zigzags, going around and around snowdrifts, and these newly-traveled paths turn out to be very bendy, twisted. The same can be said about winter paths: they are curved, snaky. Hence my, if you will, neologism: krivotrop, crooked-path” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

explanatory language time Russia
pincers of snowstorms

Sokolov explains: “I agree that the image of the pincers of snowstorms is not an easy one, it is an Imagist one, Pasternak has similar tricks, not to mention Khlebnikov. When a violent snowstorm overwhelms a poet, a proet or an ordinary romantic paranoid, it sometimes seems to him that it wants to perform a bad procedure on him, wants to mutilate his face, to blind him, to tear out, in Lermontov’s words, his sinful tongue, or even to suffocate him. The windswept pedestrian breathes greedily, now and then jets of wind rush into the cavity of his open mouth and act there so unkindly that one might compare them to inquisitorial tongs” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

explanatory intertextuality poetic device
stratocumuli

Stratocumulus clouds. A combination of stratus and cumulus clouds.

explanatory
udder-shaped

Mammatus clouds (“mammary cloud”) — a pattern of pouches that hangs underneath a raincloud and resembles an udder.

explanatory
when and whether, and if, and wherever, and while—then, therefore, and consequently, it follows

A series of indeterminate states and conditions.

time
Cozying up in the warm daze of kerosene, fearing polyps and glands, the barracks will not meet her, will not look out

Sokolov explains: “In the years we are talking about, many houses were not, pardon the expression, gasified, and in many kitchens people cooked on kerosene stoves, AKA kerosinki, which made those kitchens and the adjoining premises smell of kerosene fumes. This smell is nostalgic to me: it brings back memories of that unpretentious, poor, but in its own way cozy life of communal houses and dachas of the forties and fifties. At that time and later in the city courtyards in the evenings there was an interesting life: neighbors played soccer, dominoes, cards, sang guitar songs, drank hot drinks, discussed news and gossiped. An individual walking through the courtyard became an object of attention, a familiar person was greeted, an unfamiliar one was silently looked at to discuss who he was, how he was dressed and where he was going. In general, the courtyard community was interested in every passerby, noticed and met everyone in one way or another. They would meet them if the weather was good. In this case, the weather is bad - damp, slushy, probably windy, and the barracks, i.e. the population, the people of the barracks, will not meet the jubilant centipede, because the courtyard is empty, everyone is at home, no one wants to catch a cold, get polyps in the nose or inflammation of the glands. I did not use this term, I used a colloquial variant, usually this problem is interpreted simply: he had, let’s say, tonsils, i.e. inflammation of the tonsils. Or a case like this: the medical report says ‘he died of a myocardial infarction’, but the neighbors say: ‘of heart’. I dare to explain why fragments of bottle glass do not shine either at the pier or in garbage heaps: a certain critic admired Chekhov’s ability to describe natural phenomena and landscapes very laconically and gave an example: in a certain story Chekhov, to make it clear that the night is moonlit, offers one detail: a fragment of bottle glass shines near the pier” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

explanatory Russia author
polyps

In anatomy, a polyp is an abnormal growth of tissue projecting from a mucous membrane.

explanatory
glands

Tonsils.

explanatory
apprentice-enchanter

In the sense of an actor. Yakov takes on the role of a huntsman in his escape into the Russian backwoods. He might also be the source of all narrative voices in the novel.

explanatory character
pretending to be the admirer of the Celsius scale

As Yakov gazes out of his window and watches the world and people beyond it, he pretends to be checking the temperature.

explanatory
plywood dwelling

Barracks (Ostanin 93).

explanatory
ne’er-do-wells

In Belarusian folklore, zlydzens are humpbacked creatures resembling mean cats and dogs who wear boots and live behind stoves.

time
Sisyphean

Sisyphus — king of Ephyra (Corinth). According to Greek mythology, Sisyphus is punished by Hades, god of the underworld, for defying death by being compelled to roll a large boulder up a hill only for it to roll down once he nears the top for eternity. Also mentioned in chapter 9: “After sliding down to the bottom, they undertook the new ascent and slid again: Sisyphus after Sisyphus: What fun!” (R215/E1114).

self-reference intertextuality
having turned with the help of the flannel into something resembling a cocoon

Ostanin: “it is believed that a flannel blanket helps you fall asleep faster and have good dreams. Also here: about poetic imagination and—often—about its ascetic background and nourishment” (93). Sokolov explains this passage this way: “With the help of a flannel blanket, the lyrical hero, that is the disobedient pupil of the courier institute, that is the inspired youngster, is transformed into a cocoon before sleeping. The episode takes place in the dormitory of the aforementioned institute” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

time
cheviot

Cheviot fabric — originally made from Cheviot sheep wool. Originated in England and Scotland. Clothing motif.

motif
It came, feverishly breathing with the bowels of the bed table

Personification of winter.

poetic device
asidol

A metal cleaner.

explanatory
Maria

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Maria biscuits

Biscuits originating in England but also produced in the Soviet Union.

motif
camel

Camel. The camel has been associated with avarice, humility, stubbornness, prostitution, and, perhaps most importantly here when Yakov matures, sexuality and lust (Rowland, Animals 48–50). Animal motif.

motif
suddenly became too small

Yakov is no longer a kid.

explanatory character
Egyptian sarcophagus

A decorated ancient Egyptian coffin. Typically made of stone and displayed rather than buried.

foreign
the tower of Monsieur Flaubert

A reference to a letter from Gustave Flaubert to Ivan Turgenev in which the former wrote: “I have always tried to live in an ivory tower, but a tide of shit is beating at its walls to undermine it” (November 13, 1872; Я всегда пытался жить в башне из слоновой кости; но окружающее ее море дерьма поднимается все выше, волны бьют об ее стены с такой силой, что она вот-вот рухнет). Flaubert is famous for his usage of this specific image. This phrase and idea—a separation of art from worldly cares—has been widely used by many writers. It originates from Song of Songs 7:4–5.

foreign intertextuality religion bible
Flaubert

Gustav Flaubert (1821—1880), French realist novelist. Best known for Madame Bovary. Read it [here]((https://www.gutenberg.org/files/2413/2413-h/2413-h.htm). In an 1989 interview, Sokolov said: “I’ve never tried to prove anything. I simply make prose. I want to write like Flaubert wrote, only in our century. Flaubert, Proust — what did they teach? You don’t need all that. Literature is like playing on a fortepiano. Improvisation. Literature is good modernist jazz. But, of course, when you write a book, you’ll say something. How else could it be?” (Adamov, “Sasha Sokolov” 66).

foreign intertextuality author
one in Pisa

The Leaning Tower of Pisa (completed 1372), which leans at four degrees. Part of Pisa’s Cathedral Square (Piazza del Duomo).

foreign location
baobab

Baobab tree. Found in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Peninsula (Yemen, Oman). The boab tree is found in Australia. Can live to be over two thousand years old. Plant motif.

motif foreign
koala

Koala. Animal motif.

motif
ash

A reference to False Dmitry I, the first of several pretenders to the Russian throne who claimed to be tsarevich Dmitry Ivanovich, son of Ivan the Terrible. After coming to power through military force and ruling from 1605 to 1606, he was killed, and his body was torn apart and burned. The remains were then shot from a cannon toward Poland.

explanatory Russia
Tushino

An area in north Moscow, formerly a separate town. Most famous as the location occupied by False Dmitry II during the Time of Troubles.

Russia location
Tula

Tula — the largest city in the Tula Oblast. Located south of Moscow. Known for, among other things, samovar production.

Russia location
Tula mortar

According to Ostanin, a weapons factory has existed in Tula since 1712 (94). Sokolov adds that 200 years later his grandfather worked as the chief engineer there (“Bol’shoe pis’mo” 136).

explanatory Russia
Maria

Here, the name of the biscuits mentioned above now echoes the name of the woman. Sokolov frequently uses this device of multiple hypostases for each character. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

Looking askance at the factory, at the smokes from distant plants, and at the laborer who, straining himself, pushed along the planks the overtime wagtail with junk, the celestial body was coming up

explanatory
wagtail

Although Boguslawski translates this as “wagtail” (a bird), Sokolov explains: “In Ushakov’s dictionary, the second meaning of this word is given: A manual two-wheeled cart for transporting ore and coal to a plant” (personal correspondence, August 4, 2023).

explanatory translation
A Visit of the Ragpicker

Another painting. Sokolov suggests interpreting A Visit of the Ragpicker “as a parody of the genres of the socially concerned classic painters, particularly the Peredvizhniki (the Wanderers or Itinerants). One can recall The Arrival of the Sorcerer to a Peasant Wedding and All in the Past by Vasily Maksimov, Barge Haulers on the Volga by Ilya Repin, Troika by Vasily Perov, Over Eternal Quiet by Isaac Levitan, Moscow Courtyard by Vasily Polenov, The Morning of the Streltsy Execution and Menshikov in Berezov by Vasily Surikov, Peter the Great Interrogating the Tsarevich Alexei Petrovich by Nikolai Ge, and many others” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

explanatory
bun

Original Russian: колобком (kolobkom). Diminutive of kolob, small, round bread, or dumpling of unleavened dough. Kolobok is a character in East Slavic folk tales, depicted as a small spherical-shaped wheat bread, which escaped from its baking grandparents, and later on from various animals (rabbit, wolf and bear), but was eaten in the end by a fox.

folklore intertextuality
park of cultural recreation

Similar denominations for parks were typical across all USSR. Moscow’s most famous park is the Gorky park, which covers an area of 300 acres (120 ha) along the Moskva river and is named after the Russian writer Maksim Gorky (1868-1936). Sokolov comments: “Besides it, there are several parks of the same kind in Moscow, but they are named differently, in honor of different celebrities. There are parks of culture and recreation in many other cities” (personal communication, August 21, 2023).

intertextuality foreign
then a common apprentice courier, would not ever dare to assume that a time will come—and you will become a whipper-in

Yakov once worked as a courier but is now a whipper-in. There is another linguistic layer here based on the use of motion verbs “raz’‘ezzhat’” and “doezzhat’”: he once used to travel all the time to various places (raz-), but in the end he reached a final destination (do-).

foreign

The description of train passengers is a typical subject in Russian literature. See for example Zoshchenko’s short story entitled “A Pleasant Meeting” (1930): read the original here. Another narrative example very close to Sokolov’s is contained in Venedikt Yerofeyev’s “From Moscow to Petushki,” a novel written in the same years as “Between Dog and Wolf.” Read the passage here (in Russian). Railroad theme.

intertextuality theme
archaeopteryxes

Archaeopteryx — a genus of bird-like dinosaurs. The term comes from the ancient Greek: ἀρχαῖος (“ancient”) + πτέρυξ (“feather” or “wing”). Animal motif.

motif
at the stop named Theater, and having burst out, enthusiastically dry, after the premiere that opened another Aesopian season

According to Ostanin, this most likely refers to the Contemporary and Taganka Theatres, located in Moscow (95). Sokolov counters: “About all theatres” (“Bol’shoe pis’mo” 137). Sokolov on Moscow: “When I came to Moscow in 1989, I lived for a year, constantly changing apartments, hotels, mainly because I was “taken” by some journalists, graphomaniacs… all these people who for some reason were interested in talking to me. My wife and I counted nine addresses that we changed during the year. That is, you live, feeling that you are being torn apart a little. And you don’t belong to yourself anymore. The attention of people, of course, is flattering (before that I didn’t have such an experience that someone was interested in me), but after a few weeks you can barely walk!.. Moscow sucks, twists, you go through some kind of meat grinder. Moscow gives a lot, but it also takes a lot. There are people who love it. They are recharged by such a life… I remember we lived in a hotel near Khimki. We thought we had run away from everyone, no one knows where we are… And a few days later at midnight there’s a knock at the door… The entire Taganka Theater is standing on the threshold. They came to talk. They demand that I tell them something, speak out. They wanted to stage something. These are, of course, all wonderful people. I ran away once again, our communication didn’t continue. Perhaps they were offended…” (Slepynin).

Russia location intertextuality
Aesopian

Aesop — the famous Greek fabulist known for his animal stories. Read Aesop’s Fables here. The reference also calls to mind “Aesopian language,” which, drawing back to Aesop’s fables, is a means of encoding a message into an otherwise seemingly innocent story. For a consideration of Sokolov’s use of aesopian language in his first novel, A School for Fools, see Litus 1997.

theme time
shielding it, covering it, hiding i

Although Sokolov suggests that this reference is not there, the entire ending passage of this chapter seems to intertwine a series of allusions to Fyodor Tiutchev’s 1833 poem “Silentium”: “Молчи, скрывайся и таи” (here “Прячешь, скрываешь, таишь”), the reference to silent stars in the sky, “Любуйся” (here “Радуйся”), “Их оглушит наружный шум” (here “все-то небо оглашаешь ты кликушеским балабала́”), “Внимай их пенью” (here “внемлют сему ответу”) (personal communication, July 29, 2023). He does, however, note that the poem has been familiar to him since childhood. Read the original and an English translation here.

Foolish girl

This young girl is, as Sokolov explains, “the same wandering dirty girl who has been caught by the old women and is being led on and on, teaching and coaching her. Sympathizing with her, Yakov in his heart raises her to the rank of a passion-bearer, she is pure and bright for him” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Lyrics from the song that is sung during the children’s game gorelki (catch, stovetop). Watch the game being played here. Read the lyrics here.

intertextuality music
burdock

Burdock. Plant motif.

motif
Burn for Yakov, burn for everyone

As in ch. 2, a reference to the saying “Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого” (Hiccups, hiccups, go to Fedot, from Fedot to Yakov, from Yakov to everyone). This proverb derives from the folk belief that hiccups (a disease or demonic invasion) could be passed from one person to another. This hiccup (and the barrel further below) develops also the recurrent drinking theme.

language intertextuality intratextuality folklore theme
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
From Saint George to the Intercession, from the river’s standing to the river’s flowing and from the black fields to the white roads sheltering autumn—burn through the summer

As this blog post shows, Sokolov drew many words and combinations from Dal’’s dictionary, including those found in this sentence (sensuobsceno). An early review of the novel by Igor Burikhin drew this comparison as well: “[Sokolov’s language] can be compared to Dal’’s dictionary heard from the gateway, at the historical and metaphysical crossroads of Russia today” (273).

intertextuality
Saint George

Saint George. His saint’s day is April 23 Old Style / May 6 New Style. Known for the legend of Saint George and the Dragon. Read a version of the tale.

intertextuality religion time
Intercession

October 1 Old Style / October 14 New Style. On this day, according to folk tradition, fall and winter meet. The Christian holiday celebrates the protection (intercession, covering) of the faithful by Mary.

religion time
from the river’s standing to the river’s flowing and from the black fields to the white roads sheltering autumn

The changing seasons: frozen river vs. flowing river, fertile fields vs. snow-covered fields.

explanatory
Изморози — перейти. Курам — ходить по песку, удивленно печатая своими курьими ножками. Не любить этих птиц, но любить наблюдать, как печатают на мокром песке, не подозревая об этом; и ни о чем. Балаболки заслышались. Перекликались, но не аукались, ибо шли вместе, сплоченной стаей.

Повтор слов. Синтаксический параллелизм. Короткие предложения определяют ритм.

rhythm
перейти

The use of infinitives is typical of Yakov’s chapters. They grant the chapters in which he features a timeless quality. On a related note, Richard Borden claims that “Between Dog and Wolf takes place in a circumambient projection of its author’s linguistic consciousness and imagination and that claims for the existence of any more conventional setting would be misleading” (“Toward” 321).

Chickens. Animal motif.

motif
Курам — ходить по песку, удивленно печатая своими курьими ножками. Не любить этих птиц, но любить наблюдать, как печатают на мокром песке, не подозревая об этом; и ни о чем

As José Vergara writes, these chickens “resemble the novel’s heroes themselves, who write and write without ever really stopping to consider their ‘prints’ on the sand, surprised at times by what comes of their reflections on the page” (“Flap” 362). Animal motif.

Various characters sew in the novel. In Yakov’s eighth poem, an oriole “resews evening into night” (R172/E39). Sewing is also mentioned in Note XVI (R200/E92). Yakov sews slippers (R274/E219). Sewing theme.

theme intratextuality

Аллитерация (ск, к).

sound stylistic device
анемические ханимуны

English: honeymoon. Flowers in the flowerbed mentioned just before. Ostanin suggests that here it refers to tulips, lilies, or Chinese roses (92). However, it is likely a misspelling or play on “anemone” (commonly called wildflowers). Since they are “anemic,” they are white. According to Sokolov, these flowers are “a variety of fringed tulips, matured ones are half a meter high, but the young sprouts are, of course, small. Anemic means pale, weak, feeble” (personal communication, July 29, 2023). Plant motif.

В английском языке: honeymoon, медовый месяц. Цветы на клумбе, упомянутой ранее. Останин предполагает, что здесь речь идет о тюльпанах, лилиях или китайских розах (92). Однако, скорее всего, это неправильное написание или игра слов “анемона” (так обычно называют полевые цветы). Поскольку они “анемические”, то они белые. Согласно Соколову, эти цветы - “сорт бахромчатых тюльпанов, высота взрослых - полметра, но юные побеги, разумеется, невелики. Анемический значит бледный, слабый, вялый” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).
