Аллитерация (пре).

sound stylistic device
Сложному, смешанному духу самокруток и папирос государственного кручения

Alliteration (s, m, kr).

Аллитерация (с, м, кр).

sound stylistic device
самокруток

Self-rolled cigarettes.

explanatory
папирос

A cigarette with a paper mouthpiece, typically without a filter.

explanatory
государственного кручения

Unusual combination of words: literally meaning “state twisting” of cigarettes; it implies that cigarettes come from a state factory.

language
витать

High: to carry over the air, soar.

register/style
бытующий в усеченной каморке под лестницей

An echo of Ilya’s narrative, which describes a man living under the stairs in Orina and her grandmother’s home.

intratextuality location setting
пропадать на хранилище вод

A potential allusion to the poet and translator Spiridon Drozhzhin’s memory and, more specifically, to his house, lost (propadat’) in a water reservoir. The peasant poet Drozhzhin was Rilke’s first translator (and also a close friend). He lived on an island later submerged by the Volga just in front of the gamekeeper’s house where Sokolov lived during his period in Bezborodovo (May 1972–November 1973). According to Mario Caramitti, the character of Krylobyl is but an “hypostasis” of Drozhzhin (“Strategie,” 131).

intertextuality
хранилище вод

The water reservoir is first mentioned in chapter 2 (R159/E18). There, Ostanin identifies this dam and reservoir as the Ivankovo Reservoir, also known as the Moscow Sea (24). Located on the northern Volga, in the Moscow and Tver Oblasts, approximately 81 miles (130 km) north of Moscow.

intratextuality location Russia
эллингов

Premises for building or repairing ships ashore. Boat motif.

motif
клянча

Colloquial: to beg (of someone).

register/style
фантики

According to Ostanin, a reference to a children’s game that uses candy wrappers (92). Watch a tutorial here. Candy wrappers appear three times in the novel (R160, 248, 262/E 19, 174, 199).

explanatory intratextuality
бесстыжих

Low: shameless.

register/style
гребчих

Colloquial: oarswoman.

register/style
распущенными

Implied: hair. This detail may suggest her being of loose morals.

explanatory
чтоб видеть сплошное синее

To see the sky.

explanatory
сплошное синее

Alliteration (s).

Аллитерация (с).

sound stylistic device
синее

This color is used several times in the novel in relation to the sky and atmosphere around the Itil (cf. R154, 157, 159, 196–197, 199, 222, 249, 277).

intratextuality
демисезонное

Демисезонное пальто — “between seasons” coat. From the French demisaison. Another reference to the time setting (late spring). Clothing motif.

motif time foreign
сарафане

Sarafan: a long dress worn in Russia. A key aspect of traditional folk culture. Clothing motif.

motif Russia
кикиморы

A folkloric house spirit whose behavior matches that of the homeowner. Asks for food behind the stove or in the basement.

intertextuality folklore
Шоссе фиолетовое, в лиловых лужах, и если еще о красках, о впечатлении, то вот — мелкая молодая листва, на фоне которой дается шествие, сообщает вам впечатленье зеленого дыма.

Synesthesia (shosse fioletovoe, lilovye luzhi, zelenyj dym).

Синестезия (шоссе фиолетовое, лиловые лужи, зеленый дым).

poetic device
костлявые

In folkloric tales, the “kostliavaia” (literally, extremely thin, bony) is the incarnation of death, an allegorical figure, usually depicted as a skeleton wearing a long black cloak (or white shroud) with a scythe. Death theme.

folklore theme
Уже давно, несколько мгновений, замечал происходившее там, несколько лет замечал все из окна

Yakov spends time watching what is taking place outside his window.

explanatory character
замечал происходившее там, несколько лет замечал

Word repetition.

Повтор.

rhythm
то и знай

Set expression: oftentimes, constantly.

phraseologism time
ликующая

Here, shiny, glossy.

explanatory
сороконожка

Centipede. Animal motif.

motif
горбатая

Humpback. The image of humpbacked people and animals appears several times throughout the novel (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

intratextuality
мокрица

Woodlouse. Animal motif.

motif
стаи

Animal motif.

motif
балахоны

Colloquial: loose-fitting robe. Clothing motif.

register/style motif
Меняются декорации, освещение, обувь статисток, но жесты, гримасы, походка — не обнаруживают варьяций

Rhyme (dekoratsii, var’iatsii). Enumeration.

Рифма (декорации, варьяций). Перечисление.

rhythm rhyme
статисток

Background actresses. The scenes Yakov depicts acquire a theatrical character. Further below, he himself will be defined as a “litsedei,” a dated term for “actor.”

explanatory
октябрь

Here and below, personification of months.

Здесь и ниже, олицетворение месяцев.

poetic device time
сухарь

Literally: a dry, hard biscuit. Colloquial: heartless person.

register/style
гудрона

Tar. Here, it is a synecdoche for streets.

explanatory
топленое масло

Clarified butter.

explanatory
слякоти

Slush.

explanatory
по сточным канавам старушьих морщин сочится милдью

Sokolov explains: “The narrator compares the deep wrinkles of the old women to the ditches through which the dew flows, which has an unpleasant appearance, it resembles mildew, and thus these faces are indirectly compared to diseased leaves” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “Повествующий сравнивает глубокие морщины старух с канавами, по которым стекает роса, которая имеет неприятный вид, она напоминает милдью, и таким образом эти лица косвенно сравниваются с больными листьями” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

explanatory poetic device
милдью

Plasmopara viticola, the causal agent of grapevine downy mildew. Plant motif. In this chapter different illnesses are mentioned, and Sokolov comments: “it is an unhealthy chapter, which is understandable, because it depicts an unhealthy time in general and in particular: the depressive adolescence of the lyrical hero” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Ложная мучнистая роса винограда. Мотив растений. В этой главе упомянуты разные болезни и Соколов комментирует: “это нездоровая глава, что и понятно, ведь в ней рисуется нездоровое время вообще и в частности: депрессивное отрочество лирического героя” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

explanatory motif structure
ложно-мучнистая божья роса

“Lozhnaia muchnistaia rosa” is downy mildew, a disease that usually affects grape leaves. Plant motif.

motif
божья роса

This expression, explains Sokolov, is “used in a neutral way, it is not linked with the proverb ‘Плюй в глаза - все божья роса,’ (you spit in his eye and he will reply it’s just dew from the sky = you can’t make him blush), but with the proverb ‘Божья роса божью землю кропит’ (God’s dew sprinkles God’s earth), the meaning of which is unclear. I understand it this way: everything that is sent from above is collective, belongs to all humanity, before God we are all equal” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Это выражение, объясняет Соколов, “использовано в нейтральном смысле, оно связано не с пословицей “Плюй в глаза - все божья роса”, а с пословицей “Божья роса божью землю кропит”, смысл которой туманен, я понимаю ее так: все, что послано свыше, является общим, общечеловеческим, перед Богом все люди равны” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

phraseologism
поздно, темно и осколки бутылочного стекла не блестят ни у пристани

An allusion to Anton Chekhov’s 1886 “The Wolf,” a short story about a man’s encounter with a wolf (Ostanin 93). Read the original here.

intertextuality
мусоре мусорных

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
январь ставит болтухам ветроснежные кляпы в их тощегубые рты

The snow and wind prevents people from speaking.

explanatory
болтухам

Colloquial: babbler, chatterbox.

register/style
февраль-кривотроп

Sokolov explains: “February is called the month of crooked roads. That’s what they call it: February - crooked roads, that’s the saying. Because this month is the snowiest, and snowstorms sweep away the well-traveled tracks, and village people drive and walk on snowy spaces not straight, but in zigzags, going around and around snowdrifts, and these newly-traveled paths turn out to be very bendy, twisted. The same can be said about winter paths: they are curved, snaky. Hence my, if you will, neologism: krivotrop, crooked-path” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “Февраль называют месяцем кривых дорог. Так прямо и называют: февраль-кривые-дороги, такая, значит, поговорка. Потому что этот месяц самый снежный, и метели заметают наезженные колеи, и деревенский народ ездит и ходит по заснеженным просторам не прямо, а зигзагами, объезжая и обходя сугробы, и вот эти заново проторенные пути оказываются весьма излучистыми, извилистыми. То же самое можно сказать о зимних тропинках: они изгибистые, змеистые. Отсюда - мой, если хотите, неологизм: кривотроп” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

explanatory language time Russia
кривотроп, снабдившись клещами вьюг, тщится вытащить вещим трещоткам

Alliteration (k, v, t, shch, m).

Аллитерация (к, в, т, щ, м).

sound stylistic device
снабдившись клещами вьюг

Sokolov explains: “I agree that the image of the pincers of snowstorms is not an easy one, it is an Imagist one, Pasternak has similar tricks, not to mention Khlebnikov. When a violent snowstorm overwhelms a poet, a proet or an ordinary romantic paranoid, it sometimes seems to him that it wants to perform a bad procedure on him, wants to mutilate his face, to blind him, to tear out, in Lermontov’s words, his sinful tongue, or even to suffocate him. The windswept pedestrian breathes greedily, now and then jets of wind rush into the cavity of his open mouth and act there so unkindly that one might compare them to inquisitorial tongs” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “Клещи вьюг, согласен, образ непростой, имажинистский, да и у Пастернака встречаются подобные кунштюки, не говоря уж о Хлебникове. Когда жестокая вьюга охватывает поэта, проэта или обычного романтического параноика, ему подчас кажется, что она хочет учинить над ним нехорошую процедуру, желает изувечить ему лицо, ослепить, вырвать, по слову Лермонтова, грешный его язык, а то и задушить. Завьюженный пешеход дышит жадно, в полость его распахнутого рта то и дело врываются струи ветра и действуют там столь неласково, что впору сравнить их с инквизиторскими щипцами” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

explanatory intertextuality poetic device
трещоткам

Colloquial: chatterbox, rattle.

register/style
сухожилые языки

The tongue is, of course, a muscle, not a tendon. Here “sukhozhilye” is to be intended in its literal (adjectival) meaning: dry and weary.

language
слоисто-кучевые

Stratocumulus clouds. A combination of stratus and cumulus clouds.

explanatory
вымеобразные

Mammatus clouds (“mammary cloud”) — a pattern of pouches that hangs underneath a raincloud and resembles an udder.

explanatory
когда и поскольку, да если, да то ли, да или — тогда и постольку, и следовательно, стало быть

A series of indeterminate states and conditions.

time
когда и поскольку, да если, да то ли, да или — тогда и постольку, и следовательно, стало быть

Rhythm.

Ритм.

rhythm
никто не заметит приближения экспедиции, а и заметит — не выкаркнет, а выкаркнет

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
ютясь в керосиновом теплом чаду, опасаясь полипов и гланд, бараки не встретят, не выглянут

Sokolov explains: “In the years we are talking about, many houses were not, pardon the expression, gasified, and in many kitchens people cooked on kerosene stoves, AKA kerosinki, which made those kitchens and the adjoining premises smell of kerosene fumes. This smell is nostalgic to me: it brings back memories of that unpretentious, poor, but in its own way cozy life of communal houses and dachas of the forties and fifties. At that time and later in the city courtyards in the evenings there was an interesting life: neighbors played soccer, dominoes, cards, sang guitar songs, drank hot drinks, discussed news and gossiped. An individual walking through the courtyard became an object of attention, a familiar person was greeted, an unfamiliar one was silently looked at to discuss who he was, how he was dressed and where he was going. In general, the courtyard community was interested in every passerby, noticed and met everyone in one way or another. They would meet them if the weather was good. In this case, the weather is bad - damp, slushy, probably windy, and the barracks, i.e. the population, the people of the barracks, will not meet the jubilant centipede, because the courtyard is empty, everyone is at home, no one wants to catch a cold, get polyps in the nose or inflammation of the glands. I did not use this term, I used a colloquial variant, usually this problem is interpreted simply: he had, let’s say, tonsils, i.e. inflammation of the tonsils. Or a case like this: the medical report says ‘he died of a myocardial infarction’, but the neighbors say: ‘of heart’. I dare to explain why fragments of bottle glass do not shine either at the pier or in garbage heaps: a certain critic admired Chekhov’s ability to describe natural phenomena and landscapes very laconically and gave an example: in a certain story Chekhov, to make it clear that the night is moonlit, offers one detail: a fragment of bottle glass shines near the pier” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “В годы, о коих речь, многие дома не были, простите за выражение, газифицированы, и на многих кухнях готовили на керосиновых плитках, АКА керосинки, отчего на тех кухнях и в примыкающих к ним помещениях пахло керосиновой гарью. Этот запах мне ностальгичен: он навевает воспоминания о том неказистом, бедном, но по-своему уютном быте коммуналок и дач сороковых и пятидесятых. В то время и позже в городских дворах по вечерам имела место интересная жизнь: соседи играли в футбол, в домино, в карты, пели песни под гитару, распивали горячительные напитки, обсуждали новости и плели сплетни. Идущий через двор индивид становился объектом внимания, знакомого приветствовали, незнакомого молча рассматривали, чтобы потом обсудить, кто он такой, как одет и куда идет. Вобщем, дворовое сообщество всяким прохожим интересовалось, всякого в той или иной мере замечало, встречало. Встречало, если была хорошая погода. В данном случае погода плохая - сыро, слякотно, вероятно, дует, и бараки, читай - население, люди бараков - не встретят ликующую сороконожку, ибо двор пуст, все сидят дома, никто не хочет простыть, получить полипы в носу или воспаление гланд. Я этот термин не использовал, употребил разговорный вариант, обычно об этой проблеме толкуют просто: у него, мол гланды, то есть воспаление оных. Или такой случай: в эпикризе написано: умер от инфаркта миокарда, а соседи говорят: от сердца. Осмелюсь пояснить, отчего осколки бутылочного стекла не блестят ни у пристани, ни в мусорных кучах: некий критик восхищался умением Чехова описывать природные явления и пейзажи весьма лаконично и привел пример: в каком-то рассказе Чехов, чтобы дать понять, что ночь лунная, предлагает одну деталь: возле пристани блестит осколок бутылочного стекла” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

sound stylistic device
сизифова

Sisyphus — king of Ephyra (Corinth). According to Greek mythology, Sisyphus is punished by Hades, god of the underworld, for defying death by being compelled to roll a large boulder up a hill only for it to roll down once he nears the top for eternity. Also mentioned in chapter 9: “After sliding down to the bottom, they undertook the new ascent and slid again: Sisyphus after Sisyphus: What fun!” (R215/E1114).

intertextuality foreign intratextuality
клоаке

In ancient Rome, an underground canal for sewage disposal.

explanatory foreign
Сопоставит, сравнит два марша, отметит их сходственные черты и различия. Превратившись при помощи байки в подобье кокона

This list recalls the homework assigned by Leonardo to Nymphaea in A School for Fools.

self-reference intertextuality
Превратившись при помощи байки в подобье кокона

Ostanin: “it is believed that a flannel blanket helps you fall asleep faster and have good dreams. Also here: about poetic imagination and—often—about its ascetic background and nourishment” (93). Sokolov explains this passage this way: “With the help of a flannel blanket, the lyrical hero, that is the disobedient pupil of the courier institute, that is the inspired youngster, is transformed into a cocoon before sleeping. The episode takes place in the dormitory of the aforementioned institute” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Останин: “считается, что байковое одеяло помогает быстрее заснуть и увидеть хорошие сны. Сюда же: о поэтическом воображении и—зачастую—о его аскетической подоплёке и подпитке” (93). Соколов объясняет этот отрывок таким образом: “В подобие кокона с помощью байкового одеяла превращается перед сном лирический герой, он же ослушник разъездного училища, он же вдохновенный юноша. Дело происходит в общежитии указанного училища” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

explanatory
недуга

Literary: sickness, disease. This chapter mentions a number of illnesses.

foreign
Мария

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intratextuality intertextuality theme
маттиолой

Matthiola — a genus of flowering plant with approximately 50 species. Named after Pietro Andrea Mattioli (1501–1577). Plant motif.

motif
амалии

A type of orchid. Plant motif.

motif
дабы

Archaism: in order to. (This word has seen a growth in usage in recent decades and is used in literary language.)

register/style archaism
побудки

Reveille. French: réveil (wake up). A call typically used in the military as an alert to wake. Listen here.

music foreign
предать свидание карандашу и гуаши

Yakov wishes to write about and paint the morning scene.

карандашу и гуаши. Пришла и дышала

sound stylistic device

explanatory
Пеплогривая

neologism
цокающая ледяными подковами

The tinkling sound of ice in winter.

explanatory
цветах и цикадах

sound stylistic device
цикадах

Cicada. Animal motif.

motif
верблюдами

Camel. The camel has been associated with avarice, humility, stubbornness, prostitution, and, perhaps most importantly here when Yakov matures, sexuality and lust (Rowland, Animals 48–50). Animal motif.

motif
которое вдруг стало мало

Yakov is no longer a kid.

character explanatory
египетском саркофаге

A decorated ancient Egyptian coffin. Typically made of stone and displayed rather than buried.

foreign
в башне господина Флобера

A reference to a letter from Gustave Flaubert to Ivan Turgenev in which the former wrote: “I have always tried to live in an ivory tower, but a tide of shit is beating at its walls to undermine it” (November 13, 1872; Я всегда пытался жить в башне из слоновой кости; но окружающее ее море дерьма поднимается все выше, волны бьют об ее стены с такой силой, что она вот-вот рухнет). Flaubert is famous for his usage of this specific image. This phrase and idea—a separation of art from worldly cares—has been widely used by many writers. It originates from Song of Songs 7:4–5.

foreign intertextuality bible religion
Флобера

Gustav Flaubert (1821—1880), French realist novelist. Best known for Madame Bovary. Read it [here]((https://www.gutenberg.org/files/2413/2413-h/2413-h.htm). In an 1989 interview, Sokolov said: “I’ve never tried to prove anything. I simply make prose. I want to write like Flaubert wrote, only in our century. Flaubert, Proust — what did they teach? You don’t need all that. Literature is like playing on a fortepiano. Improvisation. Literature is good modernist jazz. But, of course, when you write a book, you’ll say something. How else could it be?” (Adamov, “Sasha Sokolov” 66).

foreign intertextuality author
Пизанской

The Leaning Tower of Pisa (completed 1372), which leans at four degrees. Part of Pisa’s Cathedral Square (Piazza del Duomo).

foreign location
баобаба

Baobab tree. Found in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Peninsula (Yemen, Oman). The boab tree is found in Australia. Can live to be over two thousand years old. Plant motif.

motif foreign
баобаба, обернувшись большим большеухим

Alliteration (b, sh).

Аллитерация (б, ш).

sound stylistic device
коала

Koala. Animal motif.

motif
вниз ушами

Set expression: usually “vniz golovoi” (upside down).

phraseologism
тушинской

An area in north Moscow, formerly a separate town. Most famous as the location occupied by False Dmitry II during the Time of Troubles.

Russia location
тушинской пригоршни праха, туго забитой в тульский мортир

Alliteration (sh, pr, n, t).

Аллитерация (ш, пр, н, т).

sound stylistic device
праха

A reference to False Dmitry I, the first of several pretenders to the Russian throne who claimed to be tsarevich Dmitry Ivanovich, son of Ivan the Terrible. After coming to power through military force and ruling from 1605 to 1606, he was killed, and his body was torn apart and burned. The remains were then shot from a cannon toward Poland.

explanatory Russia
тульский

Tula — the largest city in the Tula Oblast. Located south of Moscow. Known for, among other things, samovar production.

Russia location
тульский мортир

According to Ostanin, a weapons factory has existed in Tula since 1712 (94). Sokolov adds that 200 years later his grandfather worked as the chief engineer there (“Bol’shoe pis’mo” 136).

explanatory location
Мария

Here, the name of the biscuits mentioned above now echoes the name of the woman. Sokolov frequently uses this device of multiple hypostases for each character. rhyme
Визит тряпкореза

Another painting. Sokolov suggests interpreting A Visit of the Ragpicker “as a parody of the genres of the socially concerned classic painters, particularly the Peredvizhniki (the Wanderers or Itinerants). One can recall The Arrival of the Sorcerer to a Peasant Wedding and All in the Past by Vasily Maksimov, Barge Haulers on the Volga by Ilya Repin, Troika by Vasily Perov, Over Eternal Quiet by Isaac Levitan, Moscow Courtyard by Vasily Polenov, The Morning of the Streltsy Execution and Menshikov in Berezov by Vasily Surikov, Peter the Great Interrogating the Tsarevich Alexei Petrovich by Nikolai Ge, and many others” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Соколов предлагает трактовать Визит тряпкореза “как пародию на жанры социально озабоченных классиков, в частности, передвижников Можно вспомнить Приход колдуна на крестьянскую свадьбу и Все в прошлом Василия Максимова , Не ждали и Бурлаков на Волге Ильи Репина , Тройку Василия Перова , Над вечным покоем Исаака Левитана , Московский дворик Василия Поленова , Утро стрелецкой казни и Меншикова в Березове Василия Сурикова , Петр 1 допрашивает сына Алексея кисти Николая Ге и многие иные” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023)”

острог

Originally referred to a military fort. With the Russian expansion into Siberia and the use of exile as a punishment, ostrogs became closely associated with imprisonment and synonymous with jails.

Аллитерация (ск, т, к). Повтор глагола с разными приставками.

sound stylistic device
колобком

Diminutive of kolob, small, round bread, or dumpling of unleavened dough. Kolobok is a character in East Slavic folk tales, depicted as a small spherical-shaped wheat bread, which escaped from its baking grandparents, and later on from various animals (rabbit, wolf and bear), but was eaten in the end by a fox.

folklore intertextuality
парк культурного отдыха

Similar denominations for parks were typical across all USSR. Moscow’s most famous park is the Gorky park, which covers an area of 300 acres (120 ha) along the Moskva river and is named after the Russian writer Maksim Gorky (1868-1936). Sokolov comments: “Besides it, there are several parks of the same kind in Moscow, but they are named differently, in honor of different celebrities. There are parks of culture and recreation in many other cities” (personal communication, August 21, 2023).

Подобные названия парков были характерны для всего СССР. Самым известным парком Москвы является парк имени Горького, который занимает площадь 300 акров (120 га) вдоль Москвы-реки и назван в честь русского писателя Максима Горького (1868-1936). Соколов комментирует: “Кроме него в Москве есть несколько такого же рода парков, но они именованы по иному, в честь то есть иных знаменитостей. Парки культуры и отдыха имеются во многих других городах” (личная переписка, 21 августа 2023).

register/style
в то время обыкновенный стажирующийся разъездной, не осмелился бы и предположить, что настанет пора — и ты сделаешься доезжачим

Yakov once worked as a courier but is now a whipper-in. There is another linguistic layer here based on the use of motion verbs “raz’‘ezzhat’” and “doezzhat’”: he once used to travel all the time to various places (raz-), but in the end he reached a final destination (do-).

language explanatory
Первые метлы и скрежет хлебных лотков

Early morning movement and work: cleaners and breadmakers.

sound stylistic device
Вид пассажиров казался уныл

The description of train passengers is a typical subject in Russian literature. See for example Zoshchenko’s short story entitled “Priiatnaia vstrecha” (“A Pleasant Meeting,” 1930): read the original here. Another narrative example very close to Sokolov’s is contained in Venedikt Yerofeyev’s From Moscow to Petushki, a novel written in the same years as Between Dog and Wolf. Read the passage here (in Russian). Railroad theme.

intertextuality theme

Set expression: as ill luck would have it.

language
археоптериксов

Archaeopteryx — a genus of bird-like dinosaurs. The term comes from the ancient Greek: ἀρχαῖος (“ancient”) + πτέρυξ (“feather” or “wing”). Animal motif.

motif
на остановке Театр провинциалы после премьеры, открывшей очередной эзопов сезон

According to Ostanin, this most likely refers to the Contemporary and Taganka Theatres, located in Moscow (95). Sokolov counters: “About all theatres” (“Bol’shoe pis’mo” 137). Sokolov on Moscow: “When I came to Moscow in 1989, I lived for a year, constantly changing apartments, hotels, mainly because I was “taken” by some journalists, graphomaniacs… all these people who for some reason were interested in talking to me. My wife and I counted nine addresses that we changed during the year. That is, you live, feeling that you are being torn apart a little. And you don’t belong to yourself anymore. The attention of people, of course, is flattering (before that I didn’t have such an experience that someone was interested in me), but after a few weeks you can barely walk!.. Moscow sucks, twists, you go through some kind of meat grinder. Moscow gives a lot, but it also takes a lot. There are people who love it. They are recharged by such a life… I remember we lived in a hotel near Khimki. We thought we had run away from everyone, no one knows where we are… And a few days later at midnight there’s a knock at the door… The entire Taganka Theater is standing on the threshold. They came to talk. They demand that I tell them something, speak out. They wanted to stage something. These are, of course, all wonderful people. I ran away once again, our communication didn’t continue. Perhaps they were offended…” (Slepynin).

Russia location intertextuality
эзопов

Aesop — the famous Greek fabulist known for his animal stories. Read Aesop’s Fables here. The reference also calls to mind “Aesopian language,” which, drawing back to Aesop’s fables, is a means of encoding a message into an otherwise seemingly innocent story. For a consideration of Sokolov’s use of aesopian language in his first novel, A School for Fools, see Litus 1997.

theme time
Прячешь, скрываешь, таишь

Although Sokolov suggests that this reference is not there, the entire ending passage of this chapter seems to intertwine a series of allusions to Fyodor Tiutchev’s 1833 poem “Silentium”: “Молчи, скрывайся и таи” (here “Прячешь, скрываешь, таишь”), the reference to silent stars in the sky, “Любуйся” (here “Радуйся”), “Их оглушит наружный шум” (here “все-то небо оглашаешь ты кликушеским балабала́”), “Внимай их пенью” (here “внемлют сему ответу”) (personal communication, July 29, 2023). He does, however, note that the poem has been familiar to him since childhood. Read the original and an English translation here.

rhythm sound stylistic device
отъюношествовав

A neologism meaning “having moved away from youth.”

neologism
Неразумная девочка

This young girl is, as Sokolov explains, “the same wandering dirty girl who has been caught by the old women and is being led on and on, teaching and coaching her. Sympathizing with her, Yakov in his heart raises her to the rank of a passion-bearer, she is pure and bright for him” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Эта девочка, как объясняет Соколов, “все та же блудливая грязная девочка, которую поймали старухи и все ведут и ведут, поучая и понукая. Сочувствуя ей, Яков в сердце своем возводит ее в ранг страстотерпицы, она для него чиста и светла” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

Alliteration (gor), rhyme, enumeration.

Аллитерация (гор), рифма, перечисление.

sound stylistic device rhyme rhythm
Гори для Якова, гори для всякого

As in ch. 2, a reference to the saying “Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого” (Hiccups, hiccups, go to Fedot, from Fedot to Yakov, from Yakov to everyone). This proverb derives from the folk belief that hiccups (a disease or demonic invasion) could be passed from one person to another. This hiccup (and the barrel further below) develops also the recurrent drinking theme.

language intertextuality folklore theme intratextuality
Гори для Якова, гори для всякого

Rhyme, syntactic repetition.

Рифма, синтаксический параллелизм.

rhyme rhythm
Якова

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
От Георгия до Покрова, от рекостава до рекоплава и от черного поля до белых, осеняющих осень путей — гори вселетье

As this blog post shows, Sokolov drew many words and combinations from Dal’’s dictionary, including those found in this sentence (sensuobsceno). An early review of the novel by Igor Burikhin drew this comparison as well: “[Sokolov’s language] can be compared to Dal’’s dictionary heard from the gateway, at the historical and metaphysical crossroads of Russia today” (273).

intertextuality
Георгия

Saint George. His saint’s day is April 23 Old Style / May 6 New Style. Known for the legend of Saint George and the Dragon. Read a version of the tale.

intertextuality religion time
Покрова

October 1 Old Style / October 14 New Style. On this day, according to folk tradition, fall and winter meet. The Christian holiday celebrates the protection (intercession, covering) of the faithful by Mary.

religion time
от рекостава до рекоплава и от черного поля до белых, осеняющих осень путей

The changing seasons: frozen river vs. flowing river, fertile fields vs. snow-covered fields.
